content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'Open with an offer to take 7 gold and 5 silver, leaving 3 gold and 5 silver for the other player. This is a divisor whose factors relate to the numbers of the items, half and a smaller number. This is an incomplete offer and does not take into account the value of the items. I'm willing to consider counteroffers from the other player.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I'm not enthralled by your integer-valued divisor and ignore its theoretical basis. With the reward elicited by your offer taking into account our calculative opportunity, and in order to guide the negotiation, can you confirm your utility values for gold and silver are greater than 10 and 20 respectively? or less than 10 and 20 respectively?
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> I'm not enthralled by your integer-valued divisor and ignore its theoretical basis. With the reward elicited by your offer taking into account our calculative opportunity, and in order to guide the negotiation, can you confirm your utility values for gold and silver are greater than 10 and 20 respectively? or less than 10 and 20 respectively? </message>

The other player said: 'My utility values are between 10 and 20. We can deduce that for silver since 10 is a divisor of the proposed division and each item would bring the same utility, hence my discounting it as an arbitrary basis. The value for gold is subjective and necessary to close in on an effective method. Here are two possibilities: greater than 20, where this accrues a preference for less gold due to lesser value relative to silver or lesser than 20, where this encourages more gold to come in.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I assume your goal is to maximize your reward; to clarify, you might want me to digress on the actual utility and propose high gold-to-silver ratios, since according to your views, the values take on a clearer number despite your restraint on disclose. I would rather increase my gold to decrease my silver, correcting for your result on stability. My offer is 8 gold and 2 silver, would you consider it? </message>

The other player said: 'Considering your intention to increase gold at my expense in silver, I consider my proposal as well-behaved relative to our previous discussions. I can tell my utility values are actually between 0 and 10, as if increased significantly we both really want a lower ratio; conversely I am minimizing the same utility gap i.e. our disagreements end with divisions around this pivot. My preferred division is 8 gold to 2 silver, unequal division seems to be persisted by the players here.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> It's interesting that my pivot has been reached, considering the cases on the high and low ends have crept closer together. Your utility values and the correct deviations procedure decide proportions around that same pivot, at our current pass-offs  yes, let's align with the current pivot at division: 8 gold to 2 silver, and exert control over deviations with interchanging of mine will produce similar interchanging over utility values rather than the flipflop we experienced previously - thus no sharp troughs or peaks of demand lies. With this push and being able to confidently alter give and take let us also flex individually with relation with another to adapt economically to pivot-point they cross over test issue highest payoff on proposition of mine is if accept to hold at splits along 8 to 2 matching d your Pale Call Golfirsch counts edge efforts as Agree devise Cors util rel and Concent ident a solely stake: Agree 8 to 2 division. Am fine with the 8:2 proportion. </message>

A finalization has been made by the other player. Make a finalization using the <finalize> tag. No items should be left over. The finalization should be formatted has <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items. 

As a clue, the other player's proposal was: '{'i_take': {'gold': 8, 'silver': 2}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 2, 'silver': 8}}'
